awd_titl_txt: Including tree water storage dynamics in modeling of stomatal conductance
awd_abstract_narration:
Water stored in trees has an important role in regulating how much water the trees lose through their leaves, a process called transpiration. As plants transpire, water is lost from branches and stems more quickly than it can be replenished by water uptake from the soil by the roots. In order to prevent excessive drying, plants respond to this "hydraulic stress" by reducing transpiration rates. However, current land-surface models do not represent these hydraulic processes and the level of water storage within trees, but predict the transpiration rates based directly on soil moisture. This can produce typical daily patterns of error in simulations of transpiration. This research proposes a model to represent these missing within-tree water dynamics. The FETCH2 model resolves water flow through the tree stem to simulate realistically reductions in transpiration due to hydraulic stresses. Data from a large scale ecological disturbance experiment will be used to validate this approach. FETCH2 will be developed so that it can be coupled with other ecosystem and land-surface models. We will test the effectivity of FETCH2 by comparing the results of several ecosystem models with and without FETCH2 simulations with observations of tree water status and transpiration made in the disturbance experiment site and in a nearby undisturbed control site.  The research team has  partnered with the Ohio Water Resources Center (OWRC) to develop a hands-on activity package to illustrate porous-media flow based on the curricular activities template drafted by Project 'WET' (Water Education for Teachers), which will use games and experiments to illustrate the scientific principles at the primary school level. 

Above-ground water storage in trees plays a key role in regulating transpiration in forest canopies. Plants transpire water from the stem storage. As transpiration rates are higher than the maximal recharge rate from the soil through the roots, stem, and branches, the above-ground storage becomes depleted and stomata close to restrict transpiration in response to the negative xylem water potential. These hydraulic limitations control transpiration in forest ecosystems under both wet and dry conditions. Current land-surface models do not represent the above-ground storage in trees. These models impose water resource limitations on transpiration by directly linking stomatal conductance to soil moisture. As the intra-daily dynamics of soil moisture are very different than the dynamics of water storage in the tree xylem, the current approach leads to deviations from the observed dynamics of transpiration. As a result, land surface models produce characteristic intra-daily patterns of errors in simulations of latent heat flux. This research will develop a framework to resolve such tree hydrodynamics that could be incorporated into hydrologic, land surface, and Earth System Models to replace the current empirical link between stomatal conductance and soil moisture. The FETCH2 model resolves the water flow and water potential in the tree stem and realistically links stomatal conductance to the water potential in the xylem, while water availability in the soil provides a bottom boundary condition for the hydrodynamic system. Data from a large scale ecological disturbance experiment at a forest in Michigan will be used to validate this approach. FETCH2 simulations will be compared to observations of sap flux and stem water storage in the forest plots and to land-surface model simulation results without the hydrodynamic module. Improvements to the simulation of stomatal conductance and transpiration in atmospheric, hydrologic, and Earth system models will propagate to connected variables such as soil moisture, the surface energy budget, and gross primary productivity. By incorporating the effects of forest canopy structure, tree water storage, and hydraulic strategy on stomatal conductance, this study may impact many types and classes of climate, hydrologic, and meteorological models.

por.por_cntn:
PIs: Gil Bohrer, Ohio State University; Ashley M. Matheny, University of Texas at Austin

Plants take in carbon dioxide and lose water through openings in the leaf called stomata. Plants control the stomata openness to regulate water loss and prevent catastrophic dehydration. By changing the openness, or conductance, of the stomata plants make it harder (when stomata are closed) or easier (when open) for water vapor to be transported from the plant into the air. Understanding and predicting the water transport rate from vegetated surfaces is critical to understanding weather and climate, and also to understanding the function of vegetation. Current models of stomata conductance assume that when the soil is dry, stomata conductance decreases. However, stomata on the leaves do not have direct information about soil moisture. In reality, stomata respond to the availability of water in the branch, which is transported through the trunk and roots after being extracted from soil following a physical cascade of water pressure. The newest generation of models, known as plant-hydrodynamic models, resolve the water level inside the plants and use this information to better predict stomata conductance. Our project goal was to develop and test one such plant-hydrodynamic model. We also aimed to provide extensive observations of water content and water flows in trees at a natural forest plot at the University of Michigan Biological Station (UMBS) experimental forest (Figure 1) to support the development of the model and to support better understanding of the way stomata response to water stress.   

Intellectual merit: We have developed a new approach to measure stem water content (Figure 2). This approach allows direct observations of water content in trees, and characterization of water stress that was previously inferred, but never directly observed in continuous high frequency (minutely) measurements in forest trees in natural environments. We set up extencive observations in our two experimental site at the UMBS of water flow in more than one hundred trees, and stem water content in twenty trees. This allowed us to scale water flow from the trees (transpiration) from the tree level to the species and plot levels, and match these bottom up estimates with top-down observations of transpiration from the flux towers (Figure 3).  

The ecohydrological model FETCH2 was developed during this project (Figure 4). The model was evaluated and validated using field data (Figure 5), and used in a computer-based experiment to better understand which of the plant?s properties lead to what component of the plant?s response to water limitation.

Combining of our site observations, made with these novel methods and our model, with collaborations with water isotope researchers (Poulsen group, U. of Mich.) has led to new approaches to characterize and observe the key properties (traits) of plants that control the way they respond to water limitation. We showed that traits are coordinated due to water constraints within the trees. We showed that tree species that are typically classified as belonging to the same plant functional type may display strongly diverging water stress responses (Figure 6). We advocate the inclusion of water-stress-response strategy as part of the classification characteristics of future plant functional types in future models.

Broader impacts: Our observations could be used to validate new models and remote sensing products of vegetation function and vegetation water stress. Our model code is directly used by development teams in Lawrence Berkeley and Los Alamos National Laboratories in developing the next plant-hydrodynamic versions of the Department of Energy?s Global Earth System Model (E3SM). E3Sm is used for climate change prediction, forecasting and planning. Improving the simulation of the effects of water stress on trees in this broadly used model will lead to a large impact throughout the scientific community, and potentially with decision makers who include climate model results as part of their decision factors.

The project provided the site and research questions for training 12 undergraduate students and 5 graduate students, and helped to inspire and establish their career as future scientists. Materials and findings from the project were used in the classroom for undergradaute and gradaute classes, in Ohio State University and in the University of Texas at Austin.

We provide tree-water flow data from observations through a global open online database: SAPFLUXNET. We provide other site observations through the Ameriflux network, site IDs US-UMB and US-UMd. Our findings were presented in scientific papers and conferences, and in seminars at academic institutions. We also presented our findings to local stakeholders and state government officials during lectures titled: ?Green water on the blue planet: the invisible river that keeps Earth?s hydrologic cycle flowing?, to the Texas Senate Committee on Agriculture, Water, and Rural Affairs; and ?Transpiration and the emergence of vegetation hydrodynamics models? to the Bureau of Economic Geology, Austin TX.

    Gil Bohrer
    Figure 2. Stem water content measurements
  • We measured the amount of water that flow up the stem (sap flow) in many trees. We developed an approach to upscale these tree-level measurements to the entire forest plot (bottom-up), and compared with flux tower observations above the canopy (top down)
    Ashley Matheny
    Public Domain
    Gil Bohrer
    Fig. 3. Bottom-up scaling of transpiration observations
  • In plant-hydrodynamic models xylem water potential affects stomatal conductance, whereas in current models (not hydrodynamic) stomatal conductance is directly controlled by soil water availability and xylem water storage and transport is not calculated
